title: 105_s1750
content: SECTION 1. ADDITIONAL CERTIFICATION REGARDING DRUG-PRODUCING AND DRUG-TRANSIT COUNTRIES. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subparagraph requiring countries to cooperate with the United States in achieving compliance with the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, but also show adequate progress in meeting related plans, programs, or timetables. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to cooperate with the US in meeting plans related to the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Amendments include conforming changes to subsections regarding compliance and progress. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to cooperate with the US in meeting plans related to the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Amendments include additional requirements relating to qualified certification, such as convening a high-level contact group in the event of a certification under subsection (b)(1)(B). The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to cooperate with the US in meeting plans related to the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. A high-level contact group with specific responsibilities and benchmarks is established for each country to verify progress under the plan. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require countries to cooperate with the US in meeting plans related to the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. A high-level contact group with specific responsibilities and benchmarks is established for each country to verify progress under the plan, including specific measurable goals and deadlines. The President must submit an annual report to Congress outlining benchmarks set for countries regarding cooperation with the US on drug trafficking issues. Progress made by each country in meeting these benchmarks must be described in the report. In the case of countries with established benchmarks, the President must prioritize the progress made in meeting each benchmark when making certifications the following year. Congress recommends convening a high-level contact group for Mexico in 1998, with provisions applying to the group's activities and certification in 1999.
